Interesting question. God seems rather cruel and arbitrary in the OT precisely because that is how the world manifests itself to us. Remember the story of Cain in Genesis, who tried to follow his brother in sacrifice, but was confounded by The Lord nonetheless? How many times have you sacrificed and toiled for something, all for it to arbitrarily collapse? What else, in our ignorance, were we to make of Him?  
I think it's an excellent observation by our ancestors to characterise the world in such a way. It's basically 'yeah, life isn't fair, but resentment of creation on this basis will make it so much worse'.

Numbers also has incredible legal standards that were more progressive than legal standards maybe even now.

When God created light and darkness, it was amorphous, acorporeal light and darkness. God did not create specific celestial bodies that are a source of natural light such as the sun and moon until later. There are two messages here: one is that light does not need to come from the sun, and you know this because you get a lot of light from eletrified metal filaments. Magma casts a cool red glow. The other message is that if your God is a sun god, that wasn't even the first thing god created. The light that God brings is bigger than the sun.

The second "inconsistency" is that supposedly man plants the trees that God created before man. If you read, that's clearly not what is said. In the second part, God is talking about the "plants of the field" meaning crops in a tended field or garden. And when God says that the man will plant trees, he says that the man will plant trees which "are pleasing in his sight", meaning that man does not plant all trees. Man only plants trees which he likes, and he gets to choose from all of the trees that God already planted before God created man.

Any others that you think are actual inconsistencies? I would ask that you read them yourself first because I would assume you to be either as dishonest or dumb as the original author if you just pushed everything they list.

(2 Samuel 24:1) Again the anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and he incited David against them, saying, “Go and take a census of Israel and Judah.”

(1 Chronicles 21:1) Satan rose up against Israel and incited David to take a census of Israel.

They are both the same story as David takes a census of his people. But who commands David to take a census is obviously very different.

I think (Isaiah 45:6-7) is an interesting depiction of LORD as he describes himself saying:

"That they may know from the rising of the sun, and from the west, that there is none beside me. I am the LORD, and there is none else. I form the light, and create darkness: I make peace, and create evil: I the LORD do all these things."

My question is were the ancient Israelites often deceived or confused about who exactly they worshipped? Or are these passages showing the evolving theology of the ancient Israelites?

Not only that, but

>  For when I brought your ancestors out of Egypt and spoke to them, I did not just give them commands about burnt offerings and sacrifices, 23 but I gave them this command: Obey me, and I will be your God and you will be my people. Walk in obedience to all I command you, that it may go well with you.

And even this is a false translation! Most translations cleverly add "just" or "only" before the part about the animal sacrifice commandment. But in fact, the [original](https://biblehub.com/interlinear/jeremiah/7-22.htm) boldly says "I DID NOT speak to them or command them about burnt offerings and sacrifices...". Some object and say that "When I brought them out of the land of Egypt" refers to the time before the commandment was given, but then God would have no reason to bring it up here, and he just got done complaining that he didn't want burnt offerings like the pagan gods demanded, so that's a deflection. There is also a part about burning people at the stake, which is possibly a human sacrifice ritual, but could also be referring to the Levitical laws about putting people to death by burning: https://biblehub.com/interlinear/jeremiah/7-31.htm

There are two other repetitions of this which change it to say it's about Baal, but these are most likely not original. I do find it strange that God would mention people claiming he commanded it if it's about sacrificing to Baal, as I highly doubt they would think he wanted them to worship other gods.

> It is an extrapolation from the idea that marriage is a concession, and that we have sex so that we do not burn with lust. Thus, the idea of enhancing sexuality, so that we are always burning, even if just for our spouse, is counterproductive. We ought to minimally engage with it for the purposes of procreation and quenching thirsts.

That's an Augustinian idea and not found anywhere in the Bible, except maybe Leviticus, but that book calls literally everything "unclean", and even it permits ejaculating outside of a vagina. Paul wanted them to marry instead of burn because they were engaging in adultery and fornication; it wasn't just a feeling. Recall that lust is only wrong if you're married and lust for someone *other* than your spouse, the feeling itself isn't evil as much as Augustine and America's puritanical culture would like us to think.

> Even Protestants divide the Old Testament laws into those which are moral and those which are for ritual purity.

And this somehow falls under "moral" even though the part about not eating bacon is described with almost exactly the same language, yet it's "ritual". The only moral laws are the 10 commandments and a few others scattered about Leviticus and Deuteronomy (and even the 10 commandments are specific to the Hebrew people), the rest is ritual purity and almost all made up by scribes and priesthood and kings.
